paragraphs.text:
%md 

Run each notebook one by one so you can jump to IRIS and the Spark App Screens and evaluate the results accordingly to suggestions on notes below.

msg.data: Run each notebook one by one so you can jump to IRIS and the Spark App Screens and evaluate the results accordingly to suggestions on notes below.

paragraphs.text:
import com.intersystems.spark._

val df = spark.read.iris("IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS").selectExpr("count(ID)")

df.explain()

df.show()

msg.data:
import com.intersystems.spark._
df: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [count(ID): bigint]
== Physical Plan ==
*HashAggregate(keys=[], functions=[count(1)])
+- Exchange SinglePartition
   +- *HashAggregate(keys=[], functions=[partial_count(1)])
      +- *Scan Relation(SELECT * FROM (IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS)) [] ReadSchema: struct<>
+---------+
|count(ID)|
+---------+
|   500000|
+---------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

You will notice that:

 1. No predicate push down is happeing. The explain() shows that it is spark that is doing the count(), not IRIS. You will notice with the JDBC example below when predicate push down really happens. The plan is much simpler.
 2. A single worker is being used. I reached this conclusion because of three things:
    * Because of *Exchange SinglePartition* on the plan
    * Because as you will see bellow, IRIS doesn't appear to receive a query that filters by ID (suggesting that each worker would be reading a portion of the table)
    * Because if you look at the [Spark Executors Page](http://localhost:4141/executors/) you will see that only one of the workers (worker 0) has *Task Time* (of 7 seconds in my machine)
    * If you look at the [Query Details](http://localhost:4141/SQL/execution/?id=0), you will notice that the dataframe has not been partitioned at all. It is a big 500K. After the count is done, one row containing the final count is exchanged with the driver. 

We can now jump to the [IRIS Data Source](http://localhost:9094/csp/sys/exp/%25CSP.UI.Portal.SQL.Home.zen?$NAMESPACE=APP&$NAMESPACE=APP). 
The APP namespace starts already with 8 Cached Queries. You can ignore them.

After running the code above, two new cached queries are generated: 

**%sqlcq.APP.cls9**

```
SELECT * FROM ( SELECT * FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) ) WHERE ? = ? 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"PP","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */
```

Table *IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS* has default storage and has a standard ID a IdKey. Anton suggested that this query is used to fetch meta data and the two parameters ?=? are sent as 1=0 so that no records are actually returned, only metadata from the table.

**%sqlcq.APP.cls10**

```
SELECT ? FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"DQ","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */
```

This looks like the query it uses to fetch all the IDs so it can apply the COUNT on them on the spark cluster.

**Final Comment**

On the Spark Plan, you will notice that it issues a SELECT * instead of a SELECT ID. As the cached query on the server 
is cached with a ? I am not sure if we are receiving a * or an ID. It looks like Spark is sending a * what relly adds more 
unncessary latency to the mix.

You will notice that:

  1. No predicate push down is happeing. The explain() shows that it is spark that is doing the count(), not IRIS. You will notice with the JDBC example below when predicate push down really happens. The plan is much simpler.
  2. A single worker is being used. I reached this conclusion because of three things:
    • Because of Exchange SinglePartition on the plan
    • Because as you will see bellow, IRIS doesn’t appear to receive a query that filters by ID (suggesting that each worker would be reading a portion of the table)
    • Because if you look at the Spark Executors Page you will see that only one of the workers (worker 0) has Task Time (of 7 seconds in my machine)
    • If you look at the Query Details, you will notice that the dataframe has not been partitioned at all. It is a big 500K. After the count is done, one row containing the final count is exchanged with the driver.

We can now jump to the IRIS Data Source.
The APP namespace starts already with 8 Cached Queries. You can ignore them.

After running the code above, two new cached queries are generated:

%sqlcq.APP.cls9

SELECT * FROM ( SELECT * FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) ) WHERE ? = ? 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"PP","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */

Table IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS has default storage and has a standard ID a IdKey. Anton suggested that this query is used to fetch meta data and the two parameters ?=? are sent as 1=0 so that no records are actually returned, only metadata from the table.

%sqlcq.APP.cls10

SELECT ? FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"DQ","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */

This looks like the query it uses to fetch all the IDs so it can apply the COUNT on them on the spark cluster.

Final Comment

On the Spark Plan, you will notice that it issues a SELECT * instead of a SELECT ID. As the cached query on the server
is cached with a ? I am not sure if we are receiving a * or an ID. It looks like Spark is sending a * what relly adds more

df: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [count(ID): bigint]
== Physical Plan ==
*HashAggregate(keys=[], functions=[count(1)])
+- Exchange SinglePartition
   +- *HashAggregate(keys=[], functions=[partial_count(1)])
      +- *Scan Relation(SELECT * FROM (IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS)) [] ReadSchema: struct<>
+---------+
|count(ID)|
+---------+

+---------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

Again:
1. No predicate push down is happening.
2. A single worker is being used
3. But if you look at the [Spark Query Plan](http://localhost:4141/SQL/execution/?id=1), you will see that it didn't ignore the option()s I have passed. On that single worker, we have the table split into 20 partitions. But we are still not using the full cluster.

You can further confirm that the dataframe is being worked on a single worker by caching it:
```
val df = spark.read
    .option("numPartitions", 20)
    .option("lowerBound",1)
    .option("upperBound",500000)
    .option("partitionColumn","ID")
    .iris("IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS")
    .selectExpr("count(ID)").cache()    //Add .cache() to the end of the line
```

and then looking at the [Spark Storage](http://localhost:4141/storage/) page. There will be able to see how each partition is distributed between all the workers. I am not doing this here because it will impact the next tests.

Anyway, at least now it is partitioning the data. We can now jump to the [IRIS Data Source](http://localhost:9094/csp/sys/exp/%25CSP.UI.Portal.SQL.Home.zen?$NAMESPACE=APP&$NAMESPACE=APP). 

After running the code above, three new cached queries are generated: 

**%sqlcq.APP.cls11**

```
SELECT ? FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) WHERE ( ( ID >= ? ) & ( ID < ? ) )
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"DQ","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */
```

**%sqlcq.APP.cls12**

```
SELECT ? FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) WHERE ( ID >= ? ) 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"DQ","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */
```

**%sqlcq.APP.cls13**

```
SELECT ? FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) WHERE ( ( ID < ? ) ! ( ID IS NULL ) ) 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"DQ","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */
```

All these queries are used to fetch the partitions. Cool! It is a shame that this is not being done by different Spark Workers though.

msg.data:
Again:
1. No predicate push down is happening.
2. A single worker is being used
3. But if you look at the Spark Query Plan, you will see that it didn’t ignore the option()s I have passed. On that single worker, we have the table split into 20 partitions. But we are still not using the full cluster.

You can further confirm that the dataframe is being worked on a single worker by caching it:

val df = spark.read
    .option("numPartitions", 20)
    .option("lowerBound",1)
    .option("upperBound",500000)
    .option("partitionColumn","ID")
    .iris("IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS")
    .selectExpr("count(ID)").cache()    //Add .cache() to the end of the line

and then looking at the Spark Storage page. There will be able to see how each partition is distributed between all the workers. I am not doing this here because it will impact the next tests.

Anyway, at least now it is partitioning the data. We can now jump to the IRIS Data Source.

After running the code above, three new cached queries are generated:

%sqlcq.APP.cls11

SELECT ? FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) WHERE ( ( ID >= ? ) & ( ID < ? ) )
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"DQ","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */

%sqlcq.APP.cls12

SELECT ? FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) WHERE ( ID >= ? ) 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"DQ","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */

%sqlcq.APP.cls13

SELECT ? FROM ( IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS ) WHERE ( ( ID < ? ) ! ( ID IS NULL ) ) 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"DQ","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */

All these queries are used to fetch the partitions. Cool! It is a shame that this is not being done by different Spark Workers though.

paragraphs.text:
%md

Yes... JDBC... Now the Spark Plan is very different. It seems that no worker is working at all! That is probably because **Predicate Push Down** is finally working!

You can see the [Spark Query Plan](http://localhost:4141/SQL/execution/?id=2) graphically too. It is simple because IRIS is doing all the work! Cool!

 We can now jump to the [IRIS Data Source](http://localhost:9094/csp/sys/exp/%25CSP.UI.Portal.SQL.Home.zen?$NAMESPACE=APP&$NAMESPACE=APP). 

After running the code above, two new cached queries are generated: 

**%sqlcq.APP.cls14**

```
SELECT * FROM IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS WHERE ? = ? 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"PP","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */

```

**%sqlcq.APP.cls15**

```
SELECT ? FROM IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS WHERE ID >= ? AND ID < ? 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"PP","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */
```

**%sqlcq.APP.cls16**
```
SELECT ? FROM IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS WHERE ID < ? or ID is null 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"PP","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */
```

**%sqlcq.APP.cls17**
```
SELECT ? FROM IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS WHERE ID >= ? 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"PP","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */
```

The first query is similar to query **%sqlcq.APP.cls9** above except for the fact that it is simpler. It is there just to gather metadata which is fine.

The following three queries are similar to queries 11, 12 and 13, but also simpler. With no parenthesis.

As there is full predicate pushdown going on, it made no sense for spark to use any worker at all and that is also fine. All the work is being done by IRIS.

msg.data:
Yes… JDBC… Now the Spark Plan is very different. It seems that no worker is working at all! That is probably because Predicate Push Down is finally working!

You can see the Spark Query Plan graphically too. It is simple because IRIS is doing all the work! Cool!

We can now jump to the IRIS Data Source.

After running the code above, two new cached queries are generated:

%sqlcq.APP.cls14

SELECT * FROM IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS WHERE ? = ? 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"PP","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */

%sqlcq.APP.cls15

SELECT "ID" , "BC_TRANS_AMOUNT" , "BC_TRANS_SRC_ACC" , "BC_TRANS_SRC_ACC_NEW_BAL" , "BC_TRANS_SRC_ACC_OLD_BAL" , "BC_TRANS_IS_FRAUD" , "BC_TRANS_DEST_ACC" , "BC_TRANS_DEST_ACC_NEW_BAL" , "BC_TRANS_DEST_ACC_OLD_BAL" , "BC_TRANS_DATE" , "BC_TRANS_TYPE" , "BC_TRANS_NUM" , "BC_TRANS_WHITELISTED_BY" FROM IRISDemo . BC_TRANSACTIONS WHERE ID < ? or ID is null 
/*#OPTIONS {"xDBC":1,"xDBCFunction":"PP","xDBCServerProtocol":10,"xDBCCompileMode":1,"xDBCfastSelectSupported":1,"xDBCIsoLevel":0} */

The first query is similar to query %sqlcq.APP.cls9 above except for the fact that it is simpler. It is there just to gather metadata which is fine.

The second query is
